column4: does anyone know of a text editor that allows multiple file find and replace options?
That would be confusing having them all on the screen at the same time. o.o  Most people probably use 'sed' for that, from the command line
will sed have a desired outcome? can it edit let's say 140 .asx files at once?
Sure.  It takes a bit of a while to learn, though, if you're not familiar with regexs
You *can* just about use it to edit binary files, but I'd write a perl script rather than take that effort.
i'm not really familiar with regexs. i know there is a software for windows called editpad pro that does what i'm trying to do. i'm surprised that there isn't anything for linux.
I wouldn't see the point of doing something to 140 files in a text editor... you'd need to have 140 files open at once?  Insane. ;p
Regexs are *well worth* learning if you're going to use Linux a lot, you can do a huge amount with them
I'm definitely going to look into it. It's just i guess i'm looking for the quick, easy fix that doesn't help you learn anything. laziness i suppose.
Well, is there a specific task you want to do now?  I could tell you the command and you could try and work out how it works. ;)
sed -i -e 's/123\.123\.123\.123/example.com/g' */*.asx
Although first try 'ls */*.asx' to see if all the files get captured
how does sed know where to find what i want to replace, and replace what i want it to find?
or is that just the first step?
It just takes a list of files at the end.  The bash shell generates that list of files from '*/*.asx'

If there's a list of specific files you want to do this with then the process is slightly different, I was assuming that from the courses/ directory, all .asx files in each subdirectory would be included
To see what I mean, try cd /course; ls */*.asx
It's not ls generating the list... you can replace the 'ls' command with 'echo' and it should be the same (although less readable)
ok i got the ls to work fine...thats pretty handy!
Almost all the commands in linux just take a plain list of files and expect you to use the shell or another command to choose them... so it's a more consistent interface
the possibilities finally seem worth the headaches of learning...
I'm going to fiddle with the sed command now, thanks alot for your help!
